name: fibre cement corrugated slab production | fibre cement corrugated slab | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/111/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of fibre cement corrugated slabs. The amounts of raw materials are calculated based on the composition of fibre cement roof slate. As there are filters in the productions, air emission data are lacking but emissions from the boilers are imported via the relevant modules. Moreover, a certain amount of CO2 produced by the boiler is bound in the waste water, which is inventoried with a negative value as an avoided emission. The total yearly production is assumed to be 20'000 tonnes.;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

From the extraction of raw materials.

The activity ends with the corrugated slabs produced and the wastes treated. The dataset includes the whole manufacturing process to produce fibre cement products (raw material provision, raw material mixing, forming, post curing process coating process, and storage), transports to plant processes, and infrastructure. The dataset doesn't include dust emissions from the production process as they are collected in filters and reused in the process, and doesn't include emissions from fuel combustion processes, acid for neutralisation of the wastewater and energy requirements for administration.
category: C:Manufacturing/23:Manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products/239:Manufacture of non-metallic mineral products n.e.c./2395:Manufacture of articles of concrete, cement and plaster

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data is based on a Swiss company.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The dataset is based on the current Swiss technology. The raw materials are mixed with water to a homogeneous paste. Rotating sieving cylinders dip in this fibre cement mush which drain to the inside. Therefore the sieve surface gets covered with a layer of fleece of about 1mm which is transported with a conveyor belt. The produced endless mat is winded up on a format-cylinder until the demanded thickness is reached. With that process the fibres of the neighbour layers are interconnecting. After cutting up the mat cylinder the mat is detached from the format-cylinder and by punching and pressing automatically formed to small format slates, even and corrugated slabs.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Literature and 'ecological building material declaration' (a sort of environmental report)

exchanges.description:
Corrugated slabs are large-size fibre cement slabs with wave profile for roof covering

The technical specifications are:
Bulk density rho [kg/m3]: 1700
Thermal conductivity lamda [W/mK]: about 0.5
Weight per area [kg/m2]: 17.8 - 20.1 (used: 19)
Thickness [cm]: 1.12
Maximum size [mm]: No information

Further references: 
Weibel T. and Stritz A. (1995) Ökoinventare und Wirkungsbilanzen von Baumaterialien; Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Hochbaukonstruktionen. In: ESU-Reihe Nr. 1/95. Laboratorium für Energiesysteme, Eidg. Technische Hochschule (ETH), Zürich.
Starzner S. and Wurmer-Weiss P. (2000) ECOBIS 2000, ökologisches Baustoffinformationssystem.
SIA building materials declaration:
http://www.sia.ch/cf/oekoinfoliste.cfm?ID=2943702&Lang=d&Mfg=72&Grp=0&Produkt=, access date: Mai 2003

exchanges.description:
Stoichometric calculation, based on literature values. The CO2 emissions from combustion included in the upstream processes must be corrected to take into account CO2 binding. The amount of CO2 bound in the wastewater is 0.72 kg/m3 and is included as a negative emission to compensate the emission inventoried in the energy production module. The amount is very small because the amount of wastewater is very small (0.068 kg/kg fibre cement roof slate).

The wastewater from the production process is usually very alkaline because of a high amount of calcium oxide (quicklime) from the cement, and has to be neutralised before being released to the public sewage system. The alkaline wastewater with pH 13.5 is corrected to pH 8.5. To neutralise the wastewater, an unspecified amount of acid is added, then CO2 emissions from combustion are scrubbed through the wastewater. Since no data concerning the type and amount of acid is available it is not included in the inventory.

The CO2 binds with the calcium oxide to give lime (CaCO3) as shown in the following stoichiometric equation:.
CaO	+	CO2	->	CaCO3
56 Mol		44 Mol		100 Mol
0.91 kg		0.72 kg		1.63 kg		per m3 wastewater

The wastewater from the production process is usually very alkaline because of a high amount of calcium oxide (quicklime) from the cement, and has to be neutralised before being released to the public sewage system. The alkaline wastewater with pH 13.5 is corrected to pH 8.5. To neutralise the wastewater, an unspecified amount of acid is added, then CO2 emissions from combustion are scrubbed through the wastewater. Since no data concerning the type and amount of acid is available it is not included in the inventory.

The CO2 binds with the calcium oxide to give lime (CaCO3) as shown in the following stoichiometric equation:.
CaO	+	CO2	->	CaCO3

0.91 kg		0.72 kg		1.63 kg		per m3 wastewater
